candidates.name: Kullasit Chutipongpisit
candidates.why_elect: As a front line-clinician, I believe that I truly understand the needs and challenges in which a DHB faces when it comes to delivering care to our patients. Combined with my clinical and previous governance experiences, I would like to represent and advocate for both patients and clinicians.
candidates.why_stand: I feel that more front-line clinicians should be represented on DHBs as we truly understand the real needs and resources required to successfully and efficiently deliver care to our patients.

candidates.name: Tadhg Tim Stopford
candidates.why_elect: This is a critical time for healthcare. We are failing to improve chronic age related and lifestyle conditions, and they are bankrupting us. I am at the cutting edge of evidence based medicine, and am well placed to lead/educate ADHB into improved health outcomes and reduced costs.
candidates.why_stand: I wrote NZs first recognised cannabis course for RNZCGPs, and have taught 650 medical professionals Hemp Medicine since then. A sitting ADHB Board member has nominated me, because her MS related pain and fatigue has been improved with hemp. Hemp is the future of medicine, but it's unknown to most.

candidates.name: Patrick Cummuskey
candidates.why_elect: I'm able to contribute my experience as a volunteer ambulance officer, chair of the St John Central Auckland Area Committee and a regulatory building official, along with other skills drawn from my involvement in civil defence and the engineering community to bring a broad spectrum of knowledge to the ADHB.
candidates.why_stand: I've volunteered with St John Ambulance for over a decade and seen many parts of the health sector and the people it takes care of. I want to step up further and contribute my time and experience to making every improvement I can to improve our population health.

candidates.name: Peter Davis
candidates.why_elect: I have used the media, so I can articulate positions. I have been elected before to the hospital board and regional council, so I am aware of the responsibilities. I have lived in the area for most of my adult life, so I know it well.
candidates.why_stand: I have spent a career studying health policy and health systems, and so now is a chance to offer that expertise to the sector.

candidates.name: Pete Williams
candidates.why_elect: Aside from dealing with and understanding the ADHB as a patient, I am passionate about 'ambulance at the top of the cliff' policies. I have worked nationally and internationally for the last 20 years in the medical sector. Currently I am also on the board of Parafed Auckland.
candidates.why_stand: I am wheelchair bound, have had over 50 operations and spent close to 10% of my life in a hospital environment. I am standing, whilst sitting, to ensure all Aucklanders feel safe, informed and supported in their medical care.

candidates.name: Susan Fleming
candidates.why_elect: I am passionate about good healthcare. I have a deep understanding of our healthcare system nationally and locally. I feel deeply connected to Auckland—where I grew up and was educated. I have the experience to ensure ADHB delivers care responsibly and in a way that matters to you.
candidates.why_stand: My life has been devoted to healthcare. As an Obstetrician and Gynaecologist I could make a difference one patient at a time. As a senior Women's Health leader I could influence a service. As a board member I could use my skills and experience to improve the health of Aucklanders.

candidates.name: Jo Agnew
candidates.why_elect: I have worked in the healthcare sector as a registered nurse in different roles for 35 years and feel that I have a considerable amount of experience to share.
candidates.why_stand: The reason for me standing as a member of the Auckland District Health Board is that I feel strongly about the health of our population and I want to be involved in planning for future.

candidates.name: Adam Amos
candidates.why_elect: I've lived in Auckland all my life, and I know I'm being optimistic by saying "when I'm elected..." but when I'm elected to the Auckland DHB, I know without a doubt that any input that I have on the Auckland DHB, will definitely have a positive impact.
candidates.why_stand: I have a strong passion for high quality, first class, general healthcare, and I would like to see positive changes within the aged care sector. A single transferable vote (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, or 7) for me will not go wrong.

candidates.name: Kerrin Leoni
candidates.why_elect: I have lived in the local community for more than 10 years and have 19 years experience as a social worker, manager and now a government funding manager. I am Co-Chair and Board member of Violent Free Communities and Founder of Charitable organisation Mana Aroha providing global opportunities for youth.
candidates.why_stand: I believe Auckland is one of the best cities in the world and therefore we should have world class healthcare which meets the needs of the people. Healthy whānau and healthy families is a key priority for me which means prevention is of great importance.

candidates.name: Douglas Armstrong
candidates.why_elect: I have served on the Board and its Finance and health subcommittees for 2 terms and have demonstrated an effective governance contribution in that time.
candidates.why_stand: I believe that Auckland deserves world class healthcare and that I have the governance and experience needed on the Board to further this objective.

candidates.name: Kyle Macdonald
candidates.why_elect: I'm a psychotherapist with 20 years experience, 10 working for DHBs; I'm also Chair of the Board of the Key to Life Charitable Trust, the charity behind the work of Mike King; on the Psychotherapists Board of Aotearoa New Zealand as well as the Board of Trustees of Balmoral School.
candidates.why_stand: My stated mission in standing for the Auckland District Health Board is to take my ten years of advocating for better access to mental health services to the DHB, and in doing so work to make good mental health care more available for all Aucklanders.

candidates.name: Michelle Atkinson
candidates.why_elect: I have spent eight years in the health sector in mental health and research, and have a PGDip Health Service Management. I have personal experience with health services and have won awards for my work. I am a current ADHB Board Member and Deputy Chair of the Hospital Advisory Committee.
candidates.why_stand: I am passionate about strong healthcare governance in order to improve the system, and ensure that health services are appropriate, accessible, and safe. This is inspired by my eight years' work in the sector and informed by my own experiences using health services.

candidates.name: Ross Boswell
candidates.why_elect: I have worked in the public hospital system for 40 years, and have some understanding of primary care through my advocacy for general practice as a former Chairman of the NZMA. I am committed to the promotion of good health, and the provision of health care to those in need.
candidates.why_stand: During years of working in the health system I have grown increasingly impatient for change that would make it more responsive. While individual carers are supportive and sympathetic, the system as a whole is often inflexible and impersonal. Through participation in governance I hope I can help to improve that.

candidates.name: Zoe Brownlie
candidates.why_elect: I have worked in health for the last 15 years, in governance, management, and with patients. I'm friendly, innovative, not afraid to speak up, bring fresh ideas, and listen and represent the views of all Aucklanders.
candidates.why_stand: I’m standing to be re-elected onto the Auckland District Health Board as I’ve sat on the board for the last three years, have worked in healthcare for the last 15 years, and want to use my experience and skills, along with my passion, to keep improving healthcare for all Aucklanders.

candidates.name: Glyn Richards
candidates.why_elect: I have had extensive experience in medical practice in NZ and before that in UK and Sweden.
candidates.why_stand: I have had the privilege to work for ADHD for 45 years and wish to further assist in its progress since retiring.

candidates.name: Te Karere Scarborough
candidates.why_elect: Having spent 15 years in the charity sector here in Auckland, that has included supporting all types of whānau through advocacy, education and more recently, in a general management role at Parenting Place. I believe I'm a suitable candidate because I'm accountability to my whānau first, which keeps me grounded.
candidates.why_stand: Our healthcare system is similar to the life blood of our city. However, as a Māori male I've experienced the good, and especially the negative side of that system. I didn't see a young, proud Māori father on the board. So I'm putting my hand up as a representative.
